content.div: The first time I came to the practice I was satisfied with my experience, everything went smoothly and I got the help I needed. However, my second time I made an appointment, I had to run there but no one told me I am supposed to check in. I am not from Scotland, I live in the completely different country and also struggle understanding accents. Even when I was calling and asked the receptionist for repeating what they said, the receptionist made it even less understandable. Simply, I felt that I am not important and stupid for them. When I was waiting there for an hour, I was told to call another day. When I tried to have another appointment, I was told that I ignored two appointments before (I do not know anything about the other appointment and I was not informed about that) so I cannot have an appointment. So with almost a month of suffering tonsilitis, the doctor called me that it is not urgent and I just have to wait until it comes away.

entry.title: Average to poor quality doctors, lack base knowledge

link.title: Average to poor quality doctors, lack base knowledge
Original comment on NHS Choices website
Report this comment as offensive or unsuitable

category.label: Whether this is a comment, reply or deletion

content.div:
My experience at the practice is generally ameniable and most of the service is straight forward, but there has been some issues with Drs. My experience with nursing I would grade as average/okay, and reception staff are perfunctory.
Dr.s I find myself having to explain to them general conditions because they seem to be largely ignorant of them and just shrug their shoulders and defer, "oh, a specialist would know more about that." I spend more time during my appointment educating doctors about their own job than I am being examined, and I've only seen them twice!. When speaking about allergies, I had to educate one Dr about the peanut family and they did not know what a lupin was (a legume that is often tested for in allergies). Base knowledge of any Dr. should already know this. I saw another Dr for the first time recently for a possible ASD diagnosis, and they kept questioning me, if I read about it on the internet and suddenly think I have something, implying its all in my head, then addressed my debilitating heat sensitivity/sensory overload that causes dyspraxia type symptoms as just anxiety. A doctor would never say this. Be careful of any Dr. that dismisses symptoms as "anxiety".
I am a lot older than I look and sound in person, I know my voice sounds like a teenager's sometimes and have difficulty with trust issues and being taken seriously. I've a MSc in mental health and is part of my special interests, which is part of the reason why I speak differently, not because I know "a lot of words from Google out of health anxiety/OCD/Hypochondriasis," which is a possibility with some people
Opening up to a Dr you've never met about possibly having a personality disorder is an extremely vulnerable situation and I spent 10 minutes trying to justify my appointment and having to educate the Dr. who would not admit they just didn't know anything about it and instead, made me feel like I was a hypochondriac instead of being humble and just admitting ignorance. The Dr used zero terminology nor gave me any questions that displayed they had some base knowledge of ASD where they had the authority to treat me like that or dismiss what I'm saying. The Dr. feigned the entire appointment and then said I'd get a referral letter. Its been over two weeks and I still haven't recieved it.
I'd advise that doctors keep going on continual training to keep their knowledge up to date as their base knowledge appears questionable.
The practice manager is lovely though, B+ or an A.

entry.title: Unacceptable

link.title: Original comment on NHS Choices website
Report this comment as offensive or unsuitable

category.label: Whether this is a comment, reply or deletion

content.div:
1. Appallingly long waits to get to speak to the receptionist - if indeed you get to speak to anyone at all. This happens always.
2. Unacceptable and ridiculous waits for first available appointments. Typically 7 to 10 days (by which time a condition could be much worse) The usual excuse is &quot;so much pressure and demand on the health service&quot;. Well that doesn't help us the patients does it ? Employ more G.Ps!! I can recall back in the 80's I could see my G.P typically either the next day or the day after that.
&quot;Telephone triage&quot; - How long does that take? 10 minutes? About the average time spent in the G.P's surgery anyway.
Having turned up on time for an appointment I have often spent 20 to 30 minutes waiting in reception. A bit long, but the biggest annoyances are 1. getting to speak to the receptionist on the telephone and 2. The unacceptably long waits for appointments.
I would say &quot;avoid&quot; but I suspect that these problems are endemic throughout the NHS and doubt that any other medical practice would be much better.

It is only after having bad experiences a number of times now that I am writing this.
The reception staff leave a lot to be desired. They are unorganised, forgetful and chaotic which is a major let down to this surgery. Appointments always start between 15-30 minutes after schedule and it is difficult to get an appointment in the first place without waiting 2 weeks. I recently had an appointment which started 20 minutes late and was finished pretty quickly but needed to get a bloods test so sat back in reception. Either the GP failed to relay this to the nurse or reception did, but I was sat for another 15 minutes the asked the receptionist when I should expect to be seen - they didn't know I was waiting for the nurse then went to go and speak to her. 15 minutes later I ask again, "when am I going to be seen?" They had forgotten to ask the nurse the first time and went back into the room. I was then seen a few minutes later however this turned what could have been a 10 minute appointment if it had started on time to an hour and 10 minutes which is a joke. Other people were waiting around reception and sighing at the reception staff's incompetence. They manage to make a very simple job a complete mess. This is not the first bad experience I've had here by far. They also appear rude when talking on the phone at times and have been unhelpful to me when calling up asking for results before. Get some training for your staff as they are making a dogs dinner out of a simple job.

entry.title: Horrific Medical Prastise

link.title: Original comment on NHS Choices website
Report this comment as offensive or unsuitable

category.label: Whether this is a comment, reply or deletion

content.div:
Absolutely horrific medical practise, I wouldn't recommend anyone to seek medical advise from this surgery.
After suffering with chronic pain for the last 6 months, and repeated trips to the surgery, little help or support has been provided for my ongoing undiagnosed condition. I'm often asked if I have tried paracetamol... I've been in agony for 6 months, I think if paracetamol worked I wouldn't be in this condition. I was prescribed one set of tablets that I felt uncomfortable taking due to suffering with depression. I voiced this to one doctor, who was sympathetic and understood my concern and prescribed me a different set. The doctor required I booked a follow up appointment in a weeks time with them which I did at reception. Upon arriving to this booked appointment I was given a different doctor. This doctor then said to me that If I refused to take the previous medication prescribed, the pain I was in "couldn't be that bad" and that I mustn't be to concerned about resolving it. The doctor then went on to tell me that unless I took the tablets previously discussed with the original doctor, who was not going to refer me or offer any alternative medication. I was horrified that the doctor had said this.
On another occasion I had some blood tests, I didn't hear any news for 2 weeks so I contacted reception and they told me my blood tests had come back okay. I had already had a scan at hospital so I knew something was supposed to be coming up on this blood test. I rang the surgery the back the following day to ask the receptionist to please double check the blood test results as it didn't quite add up. The receptionist once again told me I was fine so I asked them to check the dates. The receptionist then revealed that the blood test in question wasn't even on the system, the receptionist was reading test results from a previous blood test. So they told me I was fine when no blood test results were there to read. Unless I called back to ask them to double check and then double check again I would still be under the impression that everything was fine. The receptionist contacted the lab and told me that they wasn't sure what had happened but that the lab would send the results by post. I still didn't hear anything the week after so I called again without any news. I then went to the surgery to ask in person at reception and the person said they were unsure as they couldn't really get through to the lab on the phone so they didn't know if the results were being sent. So the receptionist lied about having resolved the missing blood test results over the phone. I then had to have my blood test re done and wait a further two weeks for my results.
The person on reception is extremely rude and unhelpful. In this profession, you expect some amount of care and people skills and the NHS is there to help people in need. This person is unnaprochable, unfriendly and rude. I feel I'm inconveniencing their day by contacting the surgery. Getting through a phone call with them to get an appointment is like drawing blood from a stone.

content.div: I can't fault the standard of medical care at Blackfriars, I've been a patient there for years and the care has always been excellent. But over the last year their admin has been rapidly declining to the point where its now abysmal. Over the past year I've had a number of appointments and not once been seen on time, ranging from 10 to an amazing 45 minutes late. They've adopted a new phone system in recent months which regularly means you're left waiting an age for them to answer the phone, and occasionally no one answers at all. To top it all, they've lost my prescriptions three times now because they can't get the EPS to work and end up printing it out instead of sending it to the pharmacy and it sits on their reception for days while I repeatedly go back to the pharmacy to see if its arrived yet. If it wasn't for the good doctors and the fact that I'm in the middle of a bout of ill health and don't want the hassle of changing doctors just now I would have left months ago.

For routine appointment please book next available routine appointment.This is the same message you hear when you ring the practice. Due to increase demand on general practice I am afraid we can't see routine appointments on same day. Practice see all urgent appointments same day from telephone triage provided they are urgent. We have 35-40 DNA every week , where patients book their appointments and don't turn up.
Kind Regards
Dr B Farooq
